comments: I haven't had to use the WiFi card that much yet because the last time I had my PC set up I had access to Ethernet connection. I snagged this from my grandparents' house because everything in their house is already completely WiFi connected and this was just laying around. It has a little antenna crown with magnets and a foam foot pad, so I can just stick it to the side of my PC case or somewhere magnetizeable and it'll stay securely. This card works nicely. I don't care about having late model WiFi technology and I'd rather just use wired connections, so this fills a niche for me for when I'll need to use it.
just arrived shortly, will be installed soon !
Good for getting Internet, for me, personally, it doesn't work at its full potential, but when closer and you can't run an ethernet cable it works amazingly
Good gets the job done.
Reused wlan adapter
Great connection, easy to install. Downloads go crazy fast. I just downloaded the software onto a usb drive from the website since I don't have an optical drive.

Does great! Although if you're using the Corsair Spec 02 case with a Z390H board, don't use this. The PCIE slots do not line up for this Network adapter to fit properly. I needed to remove (bend outward like a handle actually) one of the guard bars for this adapter to lock into place. Otherwise? I haven't had anything negative about the piece of hardware working! It just doesn't play nicely with my case.

Absolute let-down. Bought this thinking it was going to give me the max speed on my internet, but to my surprise, it can barely get a signal from the 2.4 band, let alone 5. I ended up using the Intel 9260 adapter that came with the mobo. That worked amazing and gave me my max with full bars on the 5GHz band. This Asus adaptor is now sitting collecting dust in my parts box.
No drops on WiFi , very small and compacted profile. I use the 3 antennas on the desk with the extra cable and holder that came with it.
Pretty fast. Fast enough to not bottleneck my ****** internet anyways, so not really a high bar to set.

name: Asus PCE-AX3000 802.11a/b/g/n/ac/ax PCIe x1 Wi-Fi Adapter
comments: Worked straight out of the box, haven't installed any drivers (although it did come with a CD... in 2024). It requires one cable to plug into one of the USB headers on the motherboard, and it has ketchup and mustard at both ends, so that's why I'm taking a star off. Great speeds, I did a test and got 70mbps download and 19mbps upload, which I think is good.

Needed a Wi-Fi adapter after one I bought from amazon became a POS and stopped working, and my friend had this he was willing to sell to me for $20 because he bought it thinking he was going to use it. He ended up using ethernet, so he had no use for it.

Initially I wasn't going to bother with having a wifi/Bluetooth adapter but I had a cordless bluetooth keyboard in my cupboard that I'd always hoped to use. I'm now planning to replace my mouse with a bluetooth version. The current mouse needs a USB dongle to communicate through but one less thing plugged in taking up a USB port is always a good thing. The range of the signal on this card is greater than expected and it was super easy to install.
Works well. Have a good bandwidth. Bluetooth is reliable. I sometimes use cable connection when i need more speed, but is enough if you are patient with downloads.
Worked great out of the box! Didn't have any issues with installation

Does it’s job as advertised. Very reliable and stable connection for me. Just be wary if your gpu has a thick backplate and your putting the card in a pcie slot ABOVE the gpu. Metal-sticky-outtie bit coming from the pcie bracket on the Wi-Fi card may interfere.
Ok wifi card, but it gets bad signal when under my desk (yes, with the antennas) and it doesn't make it clear that you have to attach a completely separate cable for the bluetooth
Intel AX200 under the hood.

It's quick and it was easy to install into the motherboard. But on Windows 11, installing the drivers were a pain. I had to go into Device Manager, look at the hardware ID, and then copy/paste that into a search engine and find a suitable driver. At first I was looking for Asus drivers for the wifi/bluetooth, but it turns out the drivers are all from MediaTek.

name: TP-Link Archer TBE550E 802.11a/b/g/n/ac/ax PCIe x1 Wi-Fi Adapter

Good speed, very easy to install.

Easy installation. Does its job well. Ethernet's always better ofc.

The worst experience of this build. I didnt have a disc drive so I thought I was screwed, but the manual said just go to this support link and download the installation drivers. So I thought sweet its doable. Little did I know that their installation drivers are broken so I spend hours trying to figure out the problem. It wasn't my PC, it wasn't my Internet connection, it wasn't anything I did wrong. 4hrs later I finally found someone who had posted and advised to just go to the Intel website and download the Wi-fi installation drivers there. Once I did that and restarted my PC, my Wi-Fi was working.

It's decent. The signal strength is good, the response times are quick, and the added heatsink is a nice touch. It works really well about 99% of the time, but under really heavy use like moving large amounts of files across a wlan, it'll shut itself down.

comments: This has been my go-to wireless NIC for ages. They're still cheap and they've worked for me without issue.
Piece of garbage, but decent enough that I haven't needed to upgrade yet. Spend more and get a wifi 6 unit.

By far, the worst experience of the build. This card works fine, the problem is the drivers. The TP-Link drivers on the website are terrible, I was getting massive ping spikes every 20 seconds, and it got to a point where my PC would just BSOD before I could log in. I tried everything. So basically I just had to install different drivers. I think this card runs on a Realtek 8812AE chipset, so I just installed the drivers for it. When using the application, windows will automatically assume that TP-link's drivers are the best one, so you have to manually select the correct driver and installed it. Worked perfectly after doing this. My ping is only a bit worse, but worth it considering I can actually play games now.
Can be abit annoying to install under a gpu and doesn't have the greatest connection but if your just looking for cheap internet a great choice
Range is not great.

i really don't like it, even if my wifi is slow, this thing makes it even slower, making my online games almost or totally unplayable

name: EDUP EP-9651 802.11a/b/g/n/ac/ax PCIe x1 Wi-Fi Adapter
comments: Great speeds at 990+ Mbps and the bluetooth has no connection issues so far. Will update this as time goes on. The router is in the same room as the desktop sits in.

I was really suprised by this little card, both wifi and bluetooth are really good for when you have to use them. If you have the extra budget wiggle room and a free pcie slot i would definitely recommend it. Drivers work perfectly on linux too, I even use wifi for installation because of how good intel linux wifi driver support is for this chip. 100/10, would absolutely recommend.
If anyone needs it, heres the chipset info / driver downloads: https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/products/sku/204836/intel-wifi-6e-ax210-gig/downloads.html or https://www.google.com/search?q=intel+ax210+wifi+driver

I contacted ASUS for support, but they said that it was the router at my house. I looked further into it and found out that it is the channel of the 5GHz network that needed to be changed. I changed the networks 5GHz to a different channel through the router settings, and it works perfect now.

I've tried at least 3 different adapters on my system on 2 different motherboards and the Home and Pro version of Windows. It seems as if Windows sucks at managing WIFI traffic, and sadly powerline is out of the question since I only get 20mbps through it. (Must be how my home wiring is set up). For now it is working well, I just can't put my PC to sleep or the same thing will happen again for months until it fixes itself magically one day.

comments: Had a bad experience with a TP-Link wifi card (a brand I usually really like), sent it back and after doing a bit of research took a punt on one of these from Amazon. Wasn't expecting to be blown away but I was really happy that unlike the TP-Link, it connected to my home wifi at the max throughput my broadband can deliver every time. Another plus is that it uses the standard Intel drivers you download from Intel.

Meh. It's a WiFi card. Intel AX210 chipset which is basically the only relevant one now, drivers work, antennas work, comes with LP bracket and screwdriver. Power cable quality is poor and it broke for me. The chip is also not removable as if the card uses an M.2 socket, it's obscured under a permanently fixed heat spreader. Look for a card that has the M.2 connector exposed; heat spreaders and heatsinks are not necessary on a WiFi card.
A bit expensive at around £40, but at least one can reuse it for future builds

I did have a scare during installation where my Windows wasn't recognizing the device, giving an error code that "Device does not exist," but found that in addition to the specific driver that the software/Device Manager will install for this device, you also need Intel's wireless adapter driver, which was never automatically detected or recommended! Just in case anyone thinks theirs is broken. Otherwise, works just fine. Can't compare speed to other devices, but I get identical speedtest results as my iMac. Not the cheapest adapter around, but this one's got a good design with the external antenna, in which you can either lay it flat on the desk or use the included adhesive peg to hang it off the wall, rather than be stuck with antenna on the back of your tower.

This is pretty good.

I needed an adapter as my motherboard doesn't have a wifi card, and there are no ethernet ports in the space I keep my computer. I wanted TP-Link because I had purchased a router from them a little while back and it has been fantastic. Worked like a charm after installing the drivers.
I honestly chose this WiFi card because it has a black PCB.

Currently my router is 15 meters away and running the cable isn't possible because of cable management :) so I order this one and downloading speed is 37.8Mbps compared to wired PC Setup 38.2Mbps. No glitch or lag while playing games which is really important for me.
Fast enough to max out my 100Mbps cable connection. No bluetooth like some other, lesser priced cards, so will ding it a little for that.
It needs better antennas, but the stability on it is fabulous.
Fast, matches the build, works. I'm using a cat5e cable hooked up to my router so I don't use it, but it does work.
